title: BI3010: Statistical Analysis of Biological Data
text:
This 3rd year undergraduate course introduces students to key statistical theory and data analysis techniques in biological sciences. It makes strong use of R and ggplot2 but aims to give a strong fundamental and theoretical understanding of statistical modelling and associated topics.





Why do we need statistics?

Introduction to linear models (LM) and hidden assumptions

The theory of effective data visualisation

title: Undergraduate UCAS Applications and Acceptances Analysis
text:
Universities across the UK are in a pretty precarious position right now. After both Brexit and COVID the number of students has begun to fall. Especially the ever-attractive-to-senior-management-international-students-cause-¬£¬£¬£.
The well may be drying up.
And in some cases dramatically. Coventry University was a crazy ¬£90 million in debt. Dundee was talking about having to fire ca. 600 employees because senior management weren‚Äôt too good at maths (-¬£40 million appeared over night!).
Now, possibly in combination with inflation and the ‚Äúcost-of-living-crisis‚Äù, the long term viability of some universities is looking‚Ä¶ Grim. Grim dark.
This got me thinking over the weekend as to why. What‚Äôs going on with high-school students that makes it less attractive to go to uni. I can‚Äôt answer this. I‚Äôd need to do a survey of school kids and universities would never pay to get evidence to make a decision. Why waste money on research? You dumbass. Research is how they make money. They don‚Äôt pay for it.
Instead I can look at some larger scale patterns. I think universities right now see a lot of this as being due to Brexit (and latterly, the Tories not being the most welcoming to foreigners) removing the European pool of applicants (thanks O‚ÄôBrexit‚Ä¶).
But if that‚Äôs the case, then we shouldn‚Äôt see any similar kinds of trends in UK students, right? Their numbers should be relatively stable.
So that‚Äôs the idea. If UK students are relatively stable, while everything else collapses around them, then it‚Äôs probably Brexit. And strategies to target non-EU international students may well work. But if not? Well shit I guess.


I‚Äôll be skipping the data processing and going straight into the analysis. As such, I will only be using a few packages:


Code

library(mgcv)

title: Undergraduate UCAS Applications and Acceptances Analysis
text:
3.1 Fit accepted applicants model


Code
fit1 <- gam(accepted ~
             te(year, uni, origin, 
                bs = c("gp", "re", "re"),
                k = c(10, 4, 6),
                m = list(c(3, 1, 1), NA, NA)) + 
             s(age, bs = "re") +
             offset(log(applicants)),
           family = nb(),
           select = TRUE,
           method = "REML",
           data = ucas)

title: Undergraduate UCAS Applications and Acceptances Analysis
text:
3.2 Fit applicants model


Code
fit2 <- gam(applicants ~
             te(year, uni, origin, 
                bs = c("gp", "re", "re"),
                k = c(10, 4, 6),
                m = list(c(3, 1, 1), NA, NA)) + 
             s(age, bs = "re"),
           family = nb(),
           select = TRUE,
           method = "REML",
           data = ucas)

title: Undergraduate UCAS Applications and Acceptances Analysis
text:
4.1 Plot accepted applicants


Code
synth <- expand.grid(
  year = seq(from = min(ucas$year),
             to = 2029,
             by = 0.1),
  uni = unique(ucas$uni),
  origin = unique(ucas$origin),
  age = "18",
  applicants = 100000
)

preds <- predict(fit1, newdata = synth, se.fit = TRUE)

synth$fit <- exp(preds$fit)
synth$low <- exp(preds$fit - preds$se.fit * 1.96)
synth$upp <- exp(preds$fit + preds$se.fit * 1.96)

# plot

ggplot(synth) +
  geom_rect(aes(xmin = 2024, xmax = 2029, ymin = -Inf, ymax = Inf),
            fill = "lightblue", alpha = 0.1) +
  geom_ribbon(aes(x = year, ymin = low, ymax = upp), alpha = 0.1) +
  geom_line(aes(x = year, y = fit)) +
  facet_grid(uni ~ origin, scales = "free_y") +
  labs(x = "Year", y = "Acceptances per 100k Applicants") +
  theme_bw()

title: Undergraduate UCAS Applications and Acceptances Analysis
text:
4.2 Plot applications


Code
synth <- expand.grid(
  year = seq(from = min(ucas$year),

preds <- predict(fit2, newdata = synth, se.fit = TRUE)

synth$fit <- exp(preds$fit)

  geom_line(aes(x = year, y = fit)) +

  labs(x = "Year", y = "Applicants") +
  theme_bw()
